project.list: Choose project from the project database
project.label: Choose project
project.summaryLine: Begin creating your DMP by identifying your project.
project.instructions: In this step, you choose a project from your institution’s project database (if integrated) or manually input your project.
project.select: Please select the project you want to create a DMP for:
project.warning.dmp: A DMP already exists for this project
project.noprojects: No projects are assigned to you.

people.label: People involved in data management
people.summaryLine: Identify team members in your project.
people.instructions: In this step, you add individuals to the project and provide additional information about them, for example, their role in the project. To mark someone as the contact person click the person-with-envelope icon next to their role. You can change the existing information and add more contributors via the search (choose a search service and start typing the name). Please provide a minimum of one contact person as well as a data manager (it can be the same person).
people.intro: In this step, you add people involved in the project and provide additional info about them, e.g., their role. In this example, the project leader’s info has already been added and marked as the contact person (note icon with person and envelope next to their name). You can add more contributors via the search field (ensure you select the appropriate database, e.g., ORCID), or manually via the “Add contributor manually button”. Please provide a minimum of one contact person as well as a data manager (it can be the same person).

manual.input.tooltip: Use to add project contributor not found in database above

confirm.dialog.heading: Remove contributor
confirm.dialog.question:
Are you sure you want to remove this contributor?
  They are responsible for the deletion of the following datasets:

specify.label: Specify research data
specify.instructions: In this step, you specify the datasets (i.e., groups of data with similar properties) you will produce or reuse in your project.

intro.default: Research data comes in all forms and sizes. The table below helps you to describe the data sets (i.e. groups of data with similar properties) you are expecting to create during the project.
intro.reused: Research data comes in all forms and sizes. The table below helps you to describe the data sets (i.e. groups of data with similar properties) you are expecting to reuse during the project.

question.kind: What kinds of research data will you create?
question.nodata: Please explain why you won't create or analyse any research data.
question.reused: What kinds of research data will you reuse?

kind.none: No data will be created or analysed.

tab.introStorage: This step helps you to document who is allowed to see or edit your data in the project phase and to find good storage and backup solutions for your data.

dialog.title: Dataset title
dialog.fileFormat.info: Specify mime type (e.g. image/png) or file format (png)

access.heading: Planned access rights for all datasets

aria.selected: Access right for selected project members for dataset {{dataset}}
aria.other: Access right for other project members for dataset {{dataset}}
aria.public: Access right for the public for dataset  {{dataset}}

reuse.label: Reuse of data
reuse.summaryLine: Image/Describe potential reuse opportunities of your data. or  Imagine/Describe conceivable purposes for the reuse of your data.
reuse.instructions: This step helps you think about future research uses or users of your data and what potential users may require to access your data.
reuse.intro: This step helps you to think about foreseeable research uses or users of your data sets and what potential reusers require to access your data.

question.targetAudience: Who is the target audience and who could be interested in reusing the data and why?
question.tools: Indicate whether potential users need specific tools or software to access and (re-)use the data.
question.restrictedDataAccess: For the following datasets restricted access was selected, explain how others will get access to the data:

question.label: Does this dataset have to be deleted, e.g. for contractual, regulatory, or ethical reasons? If yes, please add an estimated date for the deletion, the reason for deletion, and a responsible person.

documentation.label: Documentation and data quality
documentation.summaryLine: Outline how your data will be organised throughout the project.
documentation.instructions: This step helps you to provide information on how data will be organised during the project, which data quality control measures will be used, what documentation will be prepared and made available to enable the reuse of data, and which metadata will be provided.
documentation.intro: This step helps you to provide information on how data will be organised during the project, which data quality control measures are used, what documentation will be prepared and made available to enable reuse of data, and which metadata will be provided.

question.metadata: Please indicate which metadata will be provided to help others identify, discover and reuse the data.
question.datageneration: How will the research data be generated or reused and which methods and software will be used?
question.structure: How will you structure the data and handle versioning?
question.documentation: How will you provide documentation needed to validate data analysis and facilitate data reuse?
question.dataQuality: How will the consistency and quality of data collection be controlled?
question.otherDataQuality: Please specify what other measures are taken:

storage.label: Storage and backup during the research process
storage.greeting: Step 5, Let’s elaborate on your storage, Firstname
storage.summaryLine: Define who can access and modify your data and describe your storage and backup strategies.
storage.instructions: This step helps you 1) document who is allowed to see or edit your data in the project phase and 2) find appropriate storage and backup solutions for your data.
storage.intro: Choose the best storage option for each dataset:

question.name: Storage Name
question.info: Please explain why institutional storage will not be used

legal.label: Legal and ethical aspects
legal.greeting: On to Step 6, you’re halfway there, Firstname!
legal.summaryLine: Address important legal and ethical dimensions of your project.
legal.instructions: This step helps you consider potential issues concerning personal data, intellectual property rights, and ownership and asks you for basic information on the handling of ethical issues within this project.
legal.intro: This step helps you consider potential issues concerning personal data, intellectual property rights and ownership and asks you for basic information on the handling of ethical issues within this project.
legal.heading: Legal aspects

sensitiveData.prefix: Is your data or part of it sensitive, for example
sensitiveData.suffix: , politically sensitive information, or trade secrets?

dataset.sensitiveData: Please select the datasets containing sensitive data
dataset.personalData: Please select the datasets containing personal data

question.personalData: Will personal data be collected/used as part of the project?
question.sensitiveDataSecurity: What kind of additional security measures will be taken to ensure that stored and transferred sensitive data is safe?
question.otherDataSecurityMeasures: Please specify what other measures are taken:
question.sensitiveDataAccess: Who will be authorised to access sensitive data?
question.personalDataCompliance: How will compliance with data protection be ensured?
question.otherPersonalDataCompliance: Please specify what other measures are taken:
question.legalRestrictions: Are there any other legal restrictions on how data is processed or shared?
question.legalRestrictionsDocuments: In which document(s) are these restrictions specified?
question.dataRightsAndAccessControl: List who will have the rights to control access over which dataset(s).

question.humanParticipants: Will you involve human participants in the project and thereby collect or process their personal data?
question.ethicalIssues: Beyond the use of personal data, are there any other ethical issues associated with your research?

committeeReviewed.prefix: Was your research plan reviewed by an ethics committee, the

licensing.label: Data access and licensing
licensing.summaryLine: Elaborate on future access to your data.
licensing.instructions: This step helps you to specify the access to your research output in the future: Which of your datasets will be published, which will be provided to interested persons on request only, and which need to be under lock and key, for contractual, regulatory, or ethical reasons? It also reminds you to choose a license for your open data that clearly describes the reuse conditions for potential users. To comply with the FAIR principles, metadata should be published, even if the data is closed or restricted.
licensing.intro: This step helps you to specify the access to your research output in the future: Which of your data sets will be published, which will be provided to interested persons on request only and which need to be under lock and key, for contractual, regulatory, or ethical reasons? It also reminds you to choose a license for your open data that clearly describes the reuse conditions for potential reusers. To comply with the FAIR principles, metadata should be published, even if the data are closed or restricted.
licensing.hint: Please indicate which datasets you plan to keep closed or publish. Select a license for the datasets you want to publish and estimate the release date.
licensing.info: Choose a license from the list or use the license selector to find an appropriate license.

question.hint: The release date was set to the project end date. Feel free to modify it.
question.restrictedAccessInfo: The following dataset(s) will have access restrictions, explain why and clearly describe the access conditions:
question.closedAccessInfo: Explain why the data will not be accessible (closed access):

warning.personalData: You indicated in step 6 that this dataset contains sensitive personal data. Do you really want to publish the dataset open, without restrictions?
warning.legalRestrictions: You indicated in step 6 that this dataset is subject to legal restrictions. Do you really want to publish the dataset without restrictions?

repositories.label: Specify repositories for publication and preservation
repositories.summaryLine: Choose suitable repositories for your data.
repositories.instructions: Repositories are used for sustainable data management beyond the lifetime of the project and to make data discoverable and reusable to others. If available, use a domain specific repository for your data. The search filter below may help you to find one.
repositories.intro: Use repositories to sustainably manage your data after the project’s life and to make your data discoverable and reusable. If possible, use a domain specific repository for your data. The search filter below can help you to find one. You’ll also want to set the time for how long your data should remain in the repository. This retention period can be selected in the Set retention period for datasets section
repositories.heading: Repositories

warning.deletion: The following datasets were marked for deletion: {{value}}. Are you sure they shall be preserved in a repository?

failed.all: Recommended repositories could not be loaded.
failed.recommended: Recommended repositories could not be loaded.

repositories.table.header.title: Title

costs.label: Costs
costs.summaryLine: Estimate the costs for data management in this project.
costs.instructions: In this step, you will provide information on the resources required to manage your data and a clear statement on how these costs will be covered.

infoBox.description: Researchers are encouraged to consider costs arising from data management activities. Data management costs are eligible for many funders and are thus relevant for the proposals. Please follow this

links.title: Data Management Costs Link
links.text: to find out more about possible data management costs that may also be eligible for funding.

costs.intro: In this step you are asked to provide a realistic estimation of necessary resources for data management and a clear statement on how these costs will be covered.

exist.label: Select the statement which best describes the situation in your project with respect to costs of data management.
exist.no: There are no costs dedicated to data management.
exist.yes: As outlined below, there are costs dedicated to data management.

end.label: Summary
end.greeting: Finally, let’s review your work, Firstname
end.instructions: Below is a summary of the information you provided. To add more information, go to the previous step(s).

summary.title: Summary of the information you provided:

unknown.produced: Not yet known if data will be produced.
unknown.reused: Not yet known if data will be reused.

repositories.missingexplanation: Explanation for datasets with restricted/closed access missing.

error.pattern.currency: Invalid input, please use the following format: 1234.56
error.doi: Invalid DOI. Must be formatted as 10.1234/56789 or https://doi.org/10.1234/56789 or doi:10.1234/56789

question.root: What do you want to deposit?
question.data: Is your data within the scope of copyright and related rights?
question.ownIPR: Do you own copyright and similar rights in your dataset and all its constitutive parts?
question.ensureLicensing: Are all the elements of your dataset licensed under a public license or in the Public Domain?
question.cantLicense: You need additional permission before you can deposit the data!
question.licenseInteropData: Choose licenses present in your dataset:
question.allowDerivativeWorks: Do you allow others to make derivative works?
question.shareAlike: Do you require others to share derivative works based on your data under a compatible license?
question.commercialUse: Do you allow others to make commercial use of you data?
question.decideAttributes: Do you want others to attribute your data to you?
question.software: Is your code based on existing software or is it your original work?
question.copyleft: Do you require others who modify your code to release it under a compatible licence?
question.strongCopyleft: Is your code used directly as an executable or are you licensing a library (your code will be linked)?

agpl1.name: Affero General Public License v1.0 only
agpl1.description: The GNU Affero General Public License is a free, copyleft license for software and other kinds of works, specifically designed to ensure cooperation with the community in the case of network server software.

agpl1plus.name: Affero General Public License v1.0 or later
agpl1plus.description: The GNU Affero General Public License is a free, copyleft license for software and other kinds of works, specifically designed to ensure cooperation with the community in the case of network server software. Allows content under this "any later version" grant to be redistributed under the GPL-3.0-or-later.

agpl3.name: GNU Affero General Public License v3.0 or later
agpl3.description: The AGPL license differs from the other GNU licenses in that it was built for network software. You can distribute modified versions if you keep track of the changes and the date you made them. As per usual with GNU licenses, you must license derivatives under AGPL. It provides the same restrictions and freedoms as the GPLv3 but with an additional clause which makes it so that source code must be distributed along with web publication. Since web sites and services are never distributed in the traditional sense, the AGPL is the GPL of the web.

agpl3plus.name: GNU Affero General Public License v3.0 or later
agpl3plus.description: The AGPL license differs from the other GNU licenses in that it was built for network software. You can distribute modified versions if you keep track of the changes and the date you made them. As per usual with GNU licenses, you must license derivatives under AGPL. It provides the same restrictions and freedoms as the GPLv3 but with an additional clause which makes it so that source code must be distributed along with web publication. Since web sites and services are never distributed in the traditional sense, the AGPL is the GPL of the web. This license identifier refers to the choice to use code under AGPL-3.0-or-later (i.e., AGPL-3.0 or some later version), as distinguished from use of code under AGPL-3.0-only

apache1.name: Apache License 1.0
apache1.description: This is the original Apache License which applies only to very old versions of Apache packages. Consider using a newer license. It allows you much freedom with the software.

apache1_1.name: Apache License 1.1
apache1_1.description: This license allows you much freedom with the software and differs only slightly from version 1.0. Consider using a newer version.

apache2.name: Apache License 2
apache2.description: A license that allows you much freedom with the software, including an explicit right to a patent. "State changes" means that you have to include a notice in each file you modified.

artistic1.name: Artistic License 1.0
artistic1.description: NOTE: This license has been superseded by the Artistic License, Version 2.0. This is a license for software packages with the intent of giving the original copyright holder some measure of control over his software while still remaining open source. It is flexible and allows you to distribute or sell modified versions as long as you fulfill one of various conditions. Look at section 4 in the full text for a better explanation.

artistic1Perl.name: Artistic License 1.0 (Perl)
artistic1Perl.description: NOTE: This license has been superseded by the Artistic License, Version 2.0. This is a license for software packages with the intent of giving the original copyright holder some measure of control over his software while still remaining open source. It is flexible and allows you to distribute or sell modified versions as long as you fulfill one of various conditions. Look at section 4 in the full text for a better explanation.

artistic2.name: Artistic License 2.0
artistic2.description: This is a license for software packages with the intent of giving the original copyright holder some measure of control over his software while still remaining open source. It is flexible and allows you to distribute or sell modified versions as long as you fulfill one of various conditions. Look at section 4 in the full text for a better explanation.

bsd2c.name: BSD 2-Clause "Simplified" License
bsd2c.description: The BSD 2-clause license allows you almost unlimited freedom with the software so long as you include the BSD copyright notice in it.

bsd3c.name: BSD 3-Clause "New" or "Revised" License
bsd3c.description: The BSD 3-clause license allows you almost unlimited freedom with the software so long as you include the BSD copyright notice in it. "Use trademark" in this case means you cannot use the names of the original company or its members to endorse derived products.

ccBy.name: Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International
ccBy.description: This is the standard creative commons license that gives others maximum freedom to do what they want with your work.

ccByNc.name: Creative Commons Attribution Non Commercial 4.0 International
ccByNc.description: A creative commons license that bans commercial use.

ccByNcNd.name: Creative Commons Attribution Non Commercial No Derivatives 4.0 International
ccByNcNd.description: The most restrictive creative commons license. This only allows people to download and share your work for no commercial gain and for no other purposes.

ccByNcSa.name: Creative Commons Attribution Non Commercial Share Alike 4.0 International
ccByNcSa.description: A creative commons license that bans commercial use and requires you to release any modified works under this license.

ccByNd.name: Creative Commons Attribution No Derivatives 4.0 International
ccByNd.description: The no derivatives creative commons license is straightforward; you can take a work released under this license and re-distribute it but you cannot change it.

ccBySa.name: Creative Commons Attribution Share Alike 4.0 International
ccBySa.description: This creative commons license is very similar to the regular Attribution license, but requires you to release all derivative works under this same license.

ccPublicDomain.name: Public Domain Mark
ccPublicDomain.description: The work identified as being free of known restrictions under copyright law, including all related and neighboring rights.

ccZero.name: Creative Commons Zero v1.0 Universal
ccZero.description: CC Zero enables scientists, educators, artists and other creators and owners of copyright- or database-protected content to waive those interests in their works and thereby place them as completely as possible in the public domain, so that others may freely build upon, enhance and reuse the works for any purposes without restriction under copyright or database law.

cddl1.name: Common Development and Distribution License 1.0
cddl1.description: This is a very permissive and popular license made by Sun Microsystems that also includes explicit patent grants. It is relatively simplistic in its conditions, requiring only a small amount of documentation for redistribution (applying to source as well as modified code).

cddl1_1.name: Common Development and Distribution License 1.1
cddl1_1.description: Oracle version of 1.0. This is a very permissive and popular license made by Sun Microsystems that also includes explicit patent grants. It is relatively simplistic in its conditions, requiring only a small amount of documentation for redistribution (applying to source as well as modified code).

epl1.name: Eclipse Public License 1.0
epl1.description: This license, made and used by the Eclipse Foundation, isn’t all too stringent and gives both copyright and explicit patent rights. Check the full text of the license to see how liability is accorded.

epl2.name: Eclipse Public License 2.0
epl2.description: This license, made and used by the Eclipse Foundation, isn’t all too stringent and gives both copyright and explicit patent rights. Check the full text of the license to see how liability is accorded.

gpl2.name: GNU General Public License v2.0 only
gpl2.description: Standard GNU GPL version 2 but without support for later versions i.e. you cannot relicense under GPL 3.

gpl2plus.name: GNU General Public License v2.0 or later
gpl2plus.description: You may copy, distribute and modify the software as long as you track changes/dates of in source files and keep all modifications under GPL. You can distribute your application using a GPL library commercially, but you must also disclose the source code.

gpl3.name: GNU General Public License v3.0 only
gpl3.description: You may copy, distribute and modify the software as long as you track changes/dates of in source files and keep modifications under GPL. You can distribute your application using a GPL library commercially, but you must also provide the source code. GPL 3 tries to close some loopholes in GPL 2.

gpl3plus.name: GNU General Public License v3.0 or later
gpl3plus.description: You may copy, distribute and modify the software as long as you track changes/dates of in source files and keep modifications under GPL. You can distribute your application using a GPL library commercially, but you must also provide the source code. GPL 3 tries to close some loopholes in GPL 2.

lgpl2.name: GNU Library General Public License v2 only
lgpl2.description: Standard GNU LGPL version 2.0 but without support for later versions i.e. you cannot relicense under LGPL 3.

lgpl2plus.name: GNU Library General Public License v2 or later
lgpl2plus.description: You may copy, distribute and modify the software provided that modifications are described inside the modified files and licensed for free under LGPL-2.0. Derivatives or non-separate (statically-linked) works of the software must be licensed under LGPL, but separate, parent projects don't have to be.

lgpl2_1.name: GNU Lesser General Public License v2.1 only
lgpl2_1.description: Standard GNU LGPL version 2.1 but without support for later versions i.e. you cannot relicense under LGPL 3.

lgpl2_1plus.name: GNU Lesser General Public License v2.1 or later
lgpl2_1plus.description: You may copy, distribute and modify the software provided that modifications are described inside the modified files and licensed for free under LGPL-2.1. Derivatives or non-separate (statically-linked) works of the software must be licensed under LGPL, but separate, parent projects don't have to be.

lgpl3.name: GNU Lesser General Public License v3.0 only
lgpl3.description: You may copy, distribute and modify the software provided that modifications are described inside the modified files and licensed for free under LGPL-2.1.  Derivatives or non-separate (statically-linked) works of the software must be licensed under LGPL, but separate, parent projects don't have to be. LGPL 3 tries to close some loopholes in LGPL 2.1.

lgpl3plus.name: GNU Lesser General Public License v3.0 or later
lgpl3plus.description: You may copy, distribute and modify the software provided that modifications are described inside the modified files and licensed for free under LGPL-2.1.  Derivatives or non-separate (statically-linked) works of the software must be licensed under LGPL, but separate, parent projects don't have to be. LGPL 3 tries to close some loopholes in LGPL 2.1.

mit.name: MIT License
mit.description: A short, permissive software license. Basically, you can do whatever you want as long as you include the original copyright and license.

mpl1.name: Mozilla Public License 1.0
mpl1.description: This license has been superseded by 1.1. It is a lenient license used by the Mozilla Corporation that allows you a variety of explicit freedoms with the software so long as you keep modifications under this license and distribute the original source code alongside executables. It is a good midway license; it isn’t very strict and has only straightforward requirements.

mpl1_1.name: Mozilla Public License 1.1
mpl1_1.description: This license has been superseded by 2.0. It is a lenient license used by the Mozilla Corporation that allows you a variety of explicit freedoms with the software so long as you keep modifications under this license and distribute the original source code alongside executables. It is a good midway license; it isn’t very strict and has only straightforward requirements.

mpl2.name: Mozilla Public License 2.0
mpl2.description: This is a lenient license used by the Mozilla Corporation that allows you a variety of explicit freedoms with the software so long as you keep modifications under this license and distribute the original source code alongside executables. It is a good midway license; it isn’t very strict and has only straightforward requirements.

odbl.name: Open Data Commons Open Database License v1.0
odbl.description: A copyleft license used by OpenStreetMap and others with very specific terms designed for databases.

odcBy.name: Open Data Commons Attribution License v1.0
odcBy.description: The Open Data Commons Attribution License is a license agreement intended to allow users to freely share, modify, and use this Database subject only to the attribution requirements set out in Section 4 of the license text.

pddl.name: Open Data Commons Public Domain Dedication and License
pddl.description: This license is meant to be an international, database-specific equivalent of the public domain. You cannot relicense or sublicense any database under this license because, like the public domain, after dedication you no longer own any rights to the database.

datasets.heading: Datasets
datasets.data.none: Why no data will be created or analysed
datasets.data.unknown: Not yet known if data will be created or analysed.

restrictions.label: Restrictions
restrictions.legal: Legal restrictions on data processing or sharing

documentation.heading: Documentation and data quality
documentation.data.generation: Research data generation/reuse and methods and software used
documentation.documentation: Documentation for data analysis and reuse
documentation.data.quality: Control of data consistency and quality

sensitive.data.present: Data or part of it is sensitive
sensitive.data.security: Security measures to ensure data safety

personal.data.compliance: Compliance with data protection will be ensured by

restrictions.present: There are legal restrictions on data processing/sharing
restrictions.data.rights.access: Rights and control over access to produced data

ethical.issues: Other ethical issues are associated with the research
ethical.committee.reviewed: Research plan was reviewed by an ethics committee

reuse.heading: Reuse
reuse.tools: Tools or software needed to access data

access.info.restricted: Why some datasets have access restrictions
access.info.closed: Why some datasets are closed and not accessible

compliance.INFORMED_CONSENT: by gaining informed consent for processing personal data
compliance.ANONYMISATION: by anonymisation of personal data for preservation and/or sharing (truly anonymous data are no longer considered personal data)
compliance.PSEUDONYMISATION: by pseudonymisation of personal data (the main difference with anonymisation is that pseudonymisation is reversible)
compliance.ENCRYPTION: by encryption of personal data (the encryption key must be stored separately from the data, for instance by a trusted third party)

securitymeasure.LOCKED_STORAGE: keep printouts of sensitive data in locked storage
